prelude.p: demonstrates a common pattern: when one of the vectors in a spanning set can be expressed as a linear combination of the others, that vector becomes redundant, and a smaller spanning set can be used in place of the original one. We'll give this situation a name: a set of vectors is called linearly dependentlinearlydependent if (at least) one of the vectors in the set can be written as a linear combination of other vectors in the set; otherwise the set of vectors is called linearly independentlinearlyindependent. However, it can be tedious to check each vector in a set one-by-one to see if it is a linear combination of others. Luckily, for a finite set of vectors, there is a way to check all of them all at once.

paragraphs.title: Test for Linear Dependence/Independence
paragraphs.p:
To test whether vectors \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_m are linearly dependent or independent, set up the vector equation
k_1\uvec{v}_1 + k_2\uvec{v}_2 + \dotsb + k_m\uvec{v}_m = \zerovec,
where the coefficients k_1,k_2,\dotsc,k_m are (scalar) variables.
If vector equation has a nontrivial solution in the variables k_1,k_2,\dotsc,k_m, then the vectors \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_m are linearly dependent.
Otherwise, if vector equation has only the trivial solution k_1=0,k_2=0,\dotsc,k_m=0, then the vectors \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_m are linearly independent.

aside.p: Do you see why equation always has at least the trivial solution?

prelude.p: The next activity will help you understand the Test for Linear Independence/Dependence. To keep it simple, we'll consider just three vectors at a time.

task.p:
Consider abstract vectors \uvec{u}_1,\uvec{u}_2,\uvec{u}_3, and suppose the vector equation
k_1\uvec{u}_1 + k_2\uvec{u}_2 + k_3\uvec{u}_3 = \zerovec
has a nontrivial solution. This means that there are values for the scalars k_1,k_2,k_3, at least one of which is not zero, so that equation is true.

Use some algebra to manipulate equation to demonstrate that one of the vectors can be expressed as a linear combination of the others (and hence, by definition, the vectors \uvec{u}_1,\uvec{u}_2,\uvec{u}_3 are linearly dependent).

aside.title: Careful
aside.p: Make sure you don't accidentally divide by zero!

task.p:
Consider abstract vectors \uvec{w}_1,\uvec{w}_2,\uvec{w}_3, and suppose the vector equation
k_1\uvec{w}_1 + k_2\uvec{w}_2 + k_3\uvec{w}_3 = \zerovec
has only the trivial solution. We would like to see why this means that \uvec{w}_1,\uvec{w}_2,\uvec{w}_3 are linearly independent.

Suppose they weren't: for example, suppose \uvec{v}_3 = c_1\uvec{v}_1 + c_2\uvec{v}_2 were true for some scalars c_1,c_2. Manipulate this expression for \uvec{v}_3 until is says something about equation . Do you see now why \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\uvec{v}_3 cannot satisfy the definition of linearly dependence, and hence must be linearly independent?

introduction.p: In each of the following vector spaces, practise using the Test for Linear Dependence/Independence of the given set of vectors.

hint.p: After setting up the vector equation from the test for linear dependence/independence, you are solving for the scalars k_1,k_2,k_3, not for x. On the right-hand side, the zero represents the zero vector, which in this space is the zero polynomial. What are the coefficients on powers of x in the zero polynomial? The left-hand side, being equal, must have the same coefficients.
